page.title: 04HAWTHORNE GARDENS.
page.content: Hawthorne Gardens, founded in 1920, occupies 20 acres of land and is owned by Mr Vanden Bos. In 4 acres of greenhouses he grows roses and spray chrysanthemums for sale within a 30 mile radius. Each week 13,000 cuttings of chrysanthemums are flown in from the Canary Isles. These are rooted under hot moist conditions. After a week they are transplanted. Nature is then fooled using electric lights and black-outs so that the plants have 3 weeks of 14 hour days and 10 weeks of 14 hour nights to make them flower. The gardens contracted due to an infestation of White Rust Disease, oil price increases and high labour and heating costs. In 1956 fifty people were employed - only seven now. The gardens were famous for their tomatoes but costs forced the owner to specialise in 2 varieties of flowers.
